author: By Vanessa Armstrong
title: Overlooked No More: Ellen Armstrong, ‘Marvelous, Mystifying’ Magician of Mirth
description: Carrying on a family tradition, she brought her singular act, full of illusion and humor, to Black audiences in the segregated South and on up to Philadelphia.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Prada vs. the Algorithm
description: Miuccia Prada and Raf Simons take on the style echo chamber. Fendi celebrates choice.
content: The corrosive effects of our online lives have been pretty front and center recently. So it shouldn’t be a surprise, really, that the subject has reached the runways. Or that it was Miuccia Prada and Raf Simons who took it on most directly in their Prada show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Remembering Toto Schillaci, Who Helped Usher Us Into the Future
description: For one month in 1990, Schillaci was the most beloved player in Italy, and one of the most famous players in the world.
content: Azeglio Vicini did not have any particular words of wisdom for Salvatore Schillaci. He did not send him on to the field at the Stadio Olimpico, into the white heat of a home World Cup, weighed down by some complex tactical schema. Vicini was not that sort of coach. His instructions were simple: Entra, e fai gol. Go on, and score.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Blood, Sex, Murder and Dance (No Screams)
description: Marikiscrycrycry examines fresh territory in “Goner,” but his ideas remain theatrically inert.
content: Horror movies have often taken dance as a subject, from “The Red Shoes” to “Black Swan,” “Suspiria” and this year’s “Abigail.” The reverse is much less common, and so “Goner,” a dance solo by the artist known as Marikiscrycrycry, has the advantage of exploring fresh territory. It even comes with a tantalizing content warning about flashing lights, nudity, blood, sex and murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: Who’s the Dodo Now? A Famously Extinct Bird, Reconsidered.
description: A comprehensive review of dodo science offers new insights into the biology and behavior of the much-ridiculed bird.
content: The dodo was a flightless bird about the size of a male turkey that had a long, hooked beak and the goofy charm of an emperor penguin. Its ancestor first appeared on Earth more than 25 million years ago, and by 1662, because of humans, it had vanished from Mauritius, a remote island in the Indian Ocean, the only place it ever existed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: California Firefighter Is Accused of Starting 5 Fires in Wine Country
description: A Cal Fire employee was arrested Friday on suspicion of starting several blazes in Sonoma County.
content: A California firefighter was arrested Friday morning after allegedly setting five fires in wine country during what has already been a bad year for wildfires in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike DeWine
title: I’m the Republican Governor of Ohio. Here Is the Truth About Springfield.
description: I have lived my entire life near this city. Our people and our history deserve better than to be falsely portrayed.
content: I was born in Springfield, Ohio. My wife, Fran, and I have lived our entire lives less than 10 miles from this city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: A Mouse
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: What’s Next for Rate Cuts? The Fed Is Watching Jobs and Prices.
description: A Federal Reserve official predicted quarter point rate cuts if data looked ‘fine’. But he also set out a scenario for a pause — or faster reductions.
content: Having made their first interest rate cut in more than four years this week, Federal Reserve officials are keeping their options open as they try to figure out how rapidly to lower borrowing costs in the months ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Harris Hits Core Campaign Themes in Emotional Forum With Oprah Winfrey
description: Vice President Kamala Harris spoke off the cuff, as guests included a teenager shot at her school and the family of a woman in Georgia who died as a result of the state’s abortion ban.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris harnessed the star power of one of her most powerful surrogates — and one of America’s foremost interviewers — to lay out a pitch for her campaign on Thursday, as she confronted a range of pressing issues during a livestream forum with Oprah Winfrey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Maggie Haberman, Shane Goldmacher, Nate Cohn, Diana Nguyen, Nina Feldman, Rachel Quester, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: Six Weeks to Go
description: Our colleagues on the politics desk discuss the state of the presidential race.
content: As the presidential race enters its final 45 days, we assemble a campaign round table with our colleagues from the politics desk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: One Week After Meeting, a Bloody Nose and an ‘I Love You’
description: Gregory Addicott was on another date when he met Christopher Traina. Six weeks later, they became official and began a “press tour,” introducing each other to their respective families and friends.
content: Gregory Michael Addicott was on a date with another man when he met Christopher Francis Traina on Jan. 6, 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Katie Glueck
title: A G.O.P.-Linked Group’s Contradictory Ads Cast Harris as Friend and Foe of Israel
description: The Future Coalition PAC is targeting voters in Pennsylvania and Michigan, both swing states, with contradictory messages about the vice president’s level of support for Israel.
content: A super PAC that appears to have Republican ties is trying to cast Vice President Kamala Harris in contradictory terms on Israel, pitching her as anti-Israel in a new ad that seems aimed at least partly at Jewish voters shortly after portraying her as pro-Israel in ads targeting Muslim voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Israel vs. Hamas, Hezbollah, Iran — and Itself
description: David Remnick discusses Israel’s overlapping conflicts after nearly a year of war.
content: It’s been almost a year since Oct. 7. More than 40,000 Palestinians in Gaza are dead. The hostages are not all home, and it doesn’t look like there will be a cease-fire deal that brings them home anytime soon. Israeli politics is deeply divided, and the country’s international reputation is in tatters. The Palestinian Authority is weak. A war may break out in Lebanon soon. There is no vision for the day after and no theory of what comes next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: Environmentalists Fear Subsidies for Carbon Capture Won’t Be Checked
description: Some activists are questioning whether the federal government can accurately verify a tax program for facilities that store planet-warming gases.
content: Lucrative new tax subsidies for companies that catch the planet-warming gas carbon dioxide and store it deep underground were one of the few aspects of President Biden’s 2022 climate legislation that the oil industry embraced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: The Migrant Crisis Did Not ‘Destroy’ New York. But Challenges Remain.
description: It’s been a year since Mayor Eric Adams made his ominous prediction. City officials should treat the arrival of migrants as an opportunity rather than a catastrophe, advocates say.
content: It was a year ago this month that Mayor Eric Adams announced at a town-hall meeting that the migrant crisis would “destroy New York City.” Since they were first bused from Texas in the spring of 2022, more than 216,000 migrants have passed through New York, though their arrival may not turn out to be the most damning crisis of the Adams era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: In Jan. 6 Case Filing, Trump Lawyers Again Demand Dismissal
description: Testing procedure, and perhaps the judge’s patience, the former president’s team sought to short-circuit a process to consider how much of the indictment can survive the Supreme Court’s immunity ruling.
content: For more than a year, lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump have employed aggressive tactics in defending him against two federal indictments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Harris Has a Polling Edge in Wisconsin, but Democrats Don’t Trust It
description: The vice president, who is visiting the state on Friday, has led Donald Trump there more often than not. Yet nearly everyone in Wisconsin politics believes the race will be incredibly close.
content: On paper, Vice President Kamala Harris should be feeling hopeful about Wisconsin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fernando J. Loayza Jordán
title: What Peru’s Dictator Left Behind
description: Fujimori’s authoritarian streak lives on in Peru, even in those who claim to be against the former leader’s political movement.
content: I was born in Peru in 1992, the same year President Alberto Fujimori announced he was dissolving Congress and suspended the Constitution, performing what was later called a “self-coup.” He sent tanks through the streets and arrested journalists and his political opponents, while assuming full legislative and judicial powers. He turned a democratically elected government into a dictatorship that came to define modern Peru. As long as I can remember, I’ve only known my country under the shadow of Mr. Fujimori and his political movement: Fujimorismo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Robert Gebeloff and Vincent Alban
title: How the Fastest-Growing County in Wisconsin Is Scrambling the Presidential Race
description: Madison, Wis., and its blossoming suburbs are drawing newcomers for tech and health care jobs. With a swing state in the balance, Democrats see promise.
content: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Inside a Harris Ad That Tries to Saddle Trump With Mark Robinson’s Baggage
description: A new ad placed on Friday by Kamala Harris’s campaign, without mentioning the scandal threatening the North Carolina Republican’s run for governor, seeks to taint Donald Trump by association.
content: Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign on Friday began running this 30-second ad, “Both Wrong,” on digital platforms and television stations in North Carolina. It declined to provide details on how much commercial time it had purchased, but the campaign has nearly $8 million reserved on television in North Carolina through Election Day, according to AdImpact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Constant Méheut
title: With $39 Billion Loan for Ukraine, Europe Moves Ahead Without U.S.
description: Plans for a larger sum collapsed when Hungary blocked changes requested by Washington as the price for a joint initiative.
content: The European Union’s top official said on a trip to Kyiv on Friday that Europe would offer Ukraine a loan of 35 billion euros, about $39 billion, backed by frozen Russian assets. European leaders said the loan would move forward initially without contributions from the United States, after talks between American and European officials stalled in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: Fine, Let’s Do What JD Vance Wants: Talk About Immigration
description: Yes, we need a debate over broken immigration policies. But is this really it?
content: Donald Trump and JD Vance have sparked panic over immigration in Springfield, Ohio. This week, the hosts talk about why our country’s immigration debate is now focused on a distraction instead of the core of the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Otis Davis, Who Overcame Racism to Win Olympic Gold, Dies at 92
description: At the 1960 Summer Games in Rome, he set a world record in the 400-meter race and another in the 4 x 400 relay, where he anchored the United States team’s victory.
content: Otis Davis, who was not allowed to attend the University of Alabama, in his home state, because he was Black, but flourished at the University of Oregon, which became his springboard to winning two gold medals in sprints at the 1960 Summer Olympics in Rome, died on Saturday in hospice care in North Bergen, N.J. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Michael Gold
title: Trump Says That if He Loses, ‘the Jewish People Would Have a Lot to Do’ With It
description: Speaking at a campaign event denouncing antisemitism in America, Donald Trump again attacked Jews who vote for Democrats, saying that the party had a “hold, or curse, on you.”
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, speaking on Thursday at a campaign event in Washington centered on denouncing antisemitism in America, said that “if I don’t win this election,” then “the Jewish people would have a lot to do with a loss.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Miller
title: A Surge in Breast Reductions
description: We explore why younger women are undergoing the cosmetic procedure.
content: Fashion is cyclical, and so are fashionable body types. Katharine Hepburn gave way to Marilyn Monroe, who gave way to Twiggy. Madonna was overtaken by Kate Moss. Then Kardashian voluptuousness blew up heroin chic. But when Stella Bugbee, the editor of the Times’s Styles section, pointed me to data showing a 64 percent surge in elective breast-reduction surgeries since 2019, we both knew this was more than a fad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Pat Field: Do What You Love, and You Will Make Things Happen
description: The costume designer of “Sex and the City” and “The Devil Wears Prada,” now 83, still heeds her family’s advice.
content: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, Patricia Field explains, in her own words, what continues to motivate her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Biden Will Take Cancer ‘Moonshot’ Global at Summit in Delaware
description: The president will join the leaders of Australia, India and Japan to announce a new initiative for reducing cervical cancer in the Indo-Pacific, a region with especially high rates of the disease.
content: President Biden, who is winding down his term and his life on the world stage, is taking one of his most prized personal initiatives — the cancer “moonshot” program — global.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Rosenbloom
title: From the Tetons to the Caribbean, 6 Getaways for Grown-Ups
description: We found new and revamped adults-only hotels and resorts for those who want to get away from it all.
content: If a hotel full of children is not your idea of a vacation, why not try a getaway just for grown-ups? From posh city hotels to tropical resorts, these new and recently expanded adults-only escapes beckon solo travelers, couples and friends with nature hikes, classes like pottery and macramé, spa treatments, tequila tastings and perhaps the greatest luxury of all: peace and quiet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Plagiarism Claims Are Brought Against University of Maryland’s President
description: The university’s president, Darryll J. Pines, who studies aerospace engineering, was accused of copying significant portions of a paper in 2002.
content: The University of Maryland said it was conducting a review of claims that its president, Darryll J. Pines, plagiarized significant portions of a 2002 scholarly paper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel’s Attacks on Hezbollah Intensify but Stop Short of All-Out War
description: Israel is attempting a risky strategy, increasing the intensity of its attacks in an attempt to force Hezbollah to back down, while raising the chances of an aggressive response that devolves into a land war.
content: Exploding pagers on Tuesday. Detonating walkie-talkies on Wednesday. An unusually intense barrage of bombs on Thursday. And a huge strike on southern Beirut on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raj Chetty
title: Kamala Harris Has Proposed an ‘Opportunity Economy.’ This Is How to Make It a Reality.
description: What we can learn from the science of economic opportunity.
content: At the start of her debate with Donald Trump, Kamala Harris spoke about building an “opportunity economy.” What does that mean, and how can we create one?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: These Artists Live in a Homeless Shelter
description: A gallery in a shelter near the Brooklyn Navy Yard is showcasing the work of two migrants. One of them did some of his paintings under the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at an unusual art show in Brooklyn. We’ll also look at how short trips on Citi Bikes brought in big money for some riders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: After the surprise pager attack, Israel and Hezbollah return to a familiar deadlock.
description: Israel’s attack on Hezbollah’s communication devices raised expectations of a decisive shift in their war of attrition. Instead, the fighting has returned to a standoff.
content: After the surprise of Israel’s attacks on Hezbollah communications devices this week, the war between the two sides has returned to a familiar state: deadlock.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Look Ahead at Autumn’s Big Books
description: The season’s most anticipated titles include new fiction from Sally Rooney, Richard Powers, Jean Hanff Korelitz and more, plus celebrity memoirs by Al Pacino, Cher and Ina Garten.
content: This weekend marks the official start of autumn — the equinox is on Sunday — so what better time to take a peek at the fall books we’re most excited to read? On this week’s episode, Gilbert Cruz chats with his colleagues Joumana Khatib and Anna Dubenko about the upcoming season of reading and the books on the horizon that they’re looking forward to most eagerly. They also discuss the proper way to pronounce “atoll.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Timeline: What Donald Trump Has Said About Mark Robinson
description: The former president was an early backer of Mr. Robinson’s bid to become governor of North Carolina, a race that was jolted when CNN reported that Mr. Robinson had made disturbing posts online.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump was an early backer of Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson’s campaign to become governor of North Carolina, a race that was jolted this week when CNN reported that Mr. Robinson had described himself as a “Black Nazi” in a post on a pornographic forum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a South Indian drama about sexual harassment, a film shot within a video game, a period coming-of-age movie and more.
content: A sexual-harassment allegation sends a mostly male theater troupe into a tizzy in Anand Ekarshi’s whip-smart Malayalam drama, which distills into a microcosm the contortions of a society unable to deal with misbehaving men and the women they victimize. “Aattam” takes its time in setting the stage, introducing us to the Arangu troupe — comprising 12 men and just one woman — on the eve of a big performance, featuring English theater scouts in the audience. In the preshow banter of the group, performed with fantastic naturalism by the actors, everyday sexism becomes apparent. It comes into sharp focus at their after-show party in a resort, where comments about the dressing and drinking habits of the sole heroine, Anjali (Zarin Shihab), circulate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Who Is Ibrahim Aqeel, the Hezbollah Commander Killed by Israel?
description: The senior leader, who had survived multiple assassination attempts, has been sought by the United States for bombings in the 1980s. Here is a closer look.
content: Ibrahim Aqeel, the Hezbollah commander killed by Israel on Friday in Beirut, was one of the Iran-backed Lebanese armed group’s most senior leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Boris Kachka
title: Natasha Rothwell and Samara Joy on Finding Their Voices
description: The “How to Die Alone” creator and actress and the Grammy-winning jazz singer talk about genre, improvisation and romantic comedies.
content: The television actress and writer Natasha Rothwell grew up as an itinerant Air Force kid and started her career in improvisational comedy at places like New York’s Upright Citizens Brigade; she credits both experiences with nurturing her resilience and curiosity. After writing for “Saturday Night Live” in 2014 and then appearing in the 2016 Netflix series “The Characters,” she was hired to write on “Insecure” (2016-21), Issa Rae’s breakthrough Black rom-com HBO series. Rothwell, 43, became better known, however, for portraying Kelli, the show’s frank, sexually free sidekick. She then went on to play Belinda, a disillusioned masseuse at a Hawaiian resort, on the first season of Mike White’s “The White Lotus” in 2021. She’ll reappear on that show’s third season, which airs on Max early next year. And she just finished her showrunning debut as the creator and star of “How to Die Alone,” a New York-set comedy-drama series that premiered on Hulu earlier this month. She plays Mel, a single airport employee whose near-death experience shocks her into living a deeper life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: Patricia Field: Her Joyful, Chaotic Fashion Sense Gets a Film to Match
description: “Happy Clothes” covers her work on “Emily in Paris” and “Sex and the City,” as well as her time as a tastemaker in the 1970s and ’80s underground.
content: Patricia Field likes, as she puts it, “happy clothes.” If you’ve seen her work, you get it; if you’ve watched TV, you have probably seen her work. The fashion maven is one of the most celebrated and influential costume designers of the past three decades, with “Emily in Paris,” “The Devil Wears Prada” and “Sex and the City” among her credits. Michael Selditch’s new documentary, “Happy Clothes: A Film About Patricia Field” (in theaters and on demand), follows Field as she works on the second season of the Starz comedy “Run the World,” but the feature is really a celebration of her long career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig
title: Officials Confirm Body Found Near Site of Kentucky Highway Shooting Was Suspect’s
description: The identification, made through DNA testing, affirmed the belief of officials. The body was discovered Wednesday after a 12-day manhunt.
content: DNA testing of a body found this week near the site of a Kentucky highway shooting that led to an extensive manhunt confirmed the identity as the suspect, officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What’s Your Friendship Style?
description: Are you a firefly, an evergreen, a butterfly or a wallflower? This quiz can help you find out.
content: When you host a birthday party, are you the type of person to invite everyone you know? Or do you keep it to only a few close friends?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Pulled Pork Is Party Food
description: Genevieve Ko’s saucy and satisfying recipe is also great fuel for a nap on the couch.
content: Good morning. You don’t have to be a college football fan to understand the allure of pulled pork sandwiches on a weekend afternoon. But the games do make for an excellent backdrop to the experience of cooking them, consuming them, mopping up afterward and nodding off on the couch as the crowd roars mutely on a screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Now That Rates Are Falling, Let’s Turn to Other Matters
description: The Federal Reserve has at last cut interest rates but our columnist points out a host of concerns that could weigh on financial markets.
content: The Federal Reserve has started cutting interest rates at long last, and it’s a relief that financial conditions in the United States will be easing. But it’s far too early to celebrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Kiuko Notoya and Claire Fu
title: China Says It Will ‘Gradually’ Resume Imports of Japanese Seafood
description: China imposed a ban last year after Japan began releasing treated water from the Fukushima nuclear plant into the sea. They have agreed to expand monitoring of the water.
content: China said on Friday that it would gradually resume imports of seafood from Japan, a year after banning them in response to Japan’s release of treated radioactive water from the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant into the ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Miglore
title: What Foods Should I Have on Hand for an Emergency? And Other Disaster-Related Questions, Answered
description: Plan for the future for peace of mind on the other side.
content: When wildfires, hurricanes or other climate-related disasters surge, it’s easy to panic-Google what your food and water stocks should look like in an emergency. It’s also just as easy to see asterisks like “refresh supplies every six to 12 months,” get overwhelmed and give up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Nelson DeMille, Blockbuster Author Who Thrilled Millions, Dies at 81
description: In best seller after best seller, world-weary investigators tackled military malfeasance and Russian spies, cracking jokes and beers to the delight of legions of devoted fans.
content: Nelson DeMille, a beloved and prolific author whose propulsive thrillers featuring terrorist hijackings, Russian spy schools, gruesome murders, Mafia kingpins, wartime crimes and military malfeasance made him a publishing juggernaut, died on Tuesday in Mineola, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Qasim Nauman
title: 8 California Firefighters Injured When Their Truck Rolls Over on Highway
description: The firefighters were ending a 12-hour shift battling the Airport fire, one of the biggest blazes in California this year.
content: Eight firefighters were injured when their truck rolled over on a highway near Irvine, Calif., on Thursday, as they were ending a 12-hour shift fighting one of California’s biggest blazes this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: The Netherlands Returns Hundreds of Cultural Artifacts to Indonesia
description: The repatriation, the second of its kind by the Dutch, shows a working model for returning looted treasures from Europe to former colonies around the world.
content: The Dutch government returned centuries-old stone Buddhist statues, a bejeweled serpentine armband and other looted artifacts to its former colony Indonesia on Friday, a rare example of cultural objects taken during colonialism making their way back home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Kamala Harris Tells Oprah if Somebody Breaks Into Her Home, ‘They’re Getting Shot’
description: The remarkable utterance underscored Democrats’ increasing comfort with the country’s gun culture, and how Harris is trying to use it to puncture notions about female candidates.
content: The exchange, during a livestreamed forum with Oprah Winfrey and Vice President Kamala Harris on Thursday, began with the kind of emotional set piece that has become a grim go-to for Democrats campaigning on gun safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack, Euan Ward, Aaron Boxerman and Michael Levenson
title: Senior Hezbollah Leader Is Killed in Beirut in Israeli Airstrike
description: The attack, which Lebanese officials said killed at least 14 and injured more than 60, stoked fears Israel is driving toward a full-blown war on its northern border, even as the fight in Gaza goes on.
content: Israeli fighter jets bombed an apartment building in Beirut’s densely populated southern suburbs on Friday in what the military called an attack on Hezbollah militants, including a senior commander who was wanted in the deadly 1983 bombings of the U.S. embassy and U.S. Marine Corps barracks in Beirut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: 19 More of Our Best Recipes Ever, According to You
description: You let us know what we missed from our list of NYT Cooking’s 50 greatest hits.
content: To celebrate the 10th anniversary of New York Times Cooking, we published “Our 50 Greatest Hits, According to You,” a small slice of a decade-old recipe database. But with more than 24,000 recipes and counting, we were bound to miss a few of your favorites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: 2 Stole $230 Million in Cryptocurrency and Went on a Spending Spree, U.S. Says
description: Malone Lam, 20, and Jeandiel Serrano, 21, schemed to obtain 4,100 Bitcoin from a single victim, federal prosecutors said.
content: Two men have been charged with stealing $230 million worth of cryptocurrency that they used to go on a lavish spending spree involving travel, nightclubs, luxury cars, jewelry and palatial rental properties in Los Angeles and Miami before they were caught, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Maya King
title: Democrats Seize on Robinson Scandal, Hoping to Sink Trump in a Key State
description: Kamala Harris’s campaign quickly released a new ad to run in North Carolina featuring Donald Trump’s effusive praise for Mark Robinson, the Republican candidate for governor.
content: A scandal engulfing Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson of North Carolina, the Republican nominee for governor, has Democrats feeling even more optimistic about Vice President Kamala Harris’s chances of winning a pivotal swing state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Michel Siffre, 85, Dies; Descended Into Caves to Study the Human Mind
description: He was a pioneer in chronobiology, the study of how our bodies understand the passage of time.
content: On the morning of Sept. 14, 1962, reporters and onlookers began to gather around a hole in the ground, far up in the Maritime Alps between France and Italy. A few hours later, workers rigged a rope down into the darkness; soon they pulled out a small, sturdily built man named Michel Siffre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Miller
title: The Power of a Smaller Breast
description: Breast reduction is all the rage in cosmetic surgery. Are women asserting their independence or capitulating to yet another impossible standard of beauty?
content: The women walk into the surgeons’ offices with photos cued up on their phones. Miley Cyrus. Keira Knightley. Bella Hadid. I want my breasts to look like this, they say. They’ve already spent hours on YouTube watching plastic surgeons’ infomercials, on Instagram poring over before-and-afters, and on TikTok, where an army of ordinary women post about their breast reductions. “Ask me,” they say. Whether their nipple sensation has changed. What their boyfriends said. Whether they cared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters, Ruth Igielnik and Clyde McGrady
title: These Voters Don’t Want to Commit to Trump or Harris. Here’s Why.
description: Those still weighing their options are more likely  to be young, Black or Latino — and struggling. Many see their choice as the “lesser of two evils.”
content: More than other voters, they tend to be young, and Black or Hispanic. They get more news from social media than most voters do. They worry about their economic security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Man the U.S. Says Financed Hezbollah Admits Trying to Evade Sanctions
description: Mohammad Ibrahim Bazzi pleaded guilty in Brooklyn federal court to conspiring to violate Treasury Department prohibitions.
content: For years, U.S. authorities said, Mohammad Ibrahim Bazzi funneled millions of dollars to Hezbollah, the militia backed by Iran and based in Lebanon that is currently clashing with Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘The Penguin’ Review: The Dark Blight
description: The HBO series starring an unrecognizable Colin Farrell is further proof that there is no fun in the Batman universe.
content: When was fun banished from Batman’s world? Certainly the tide turned with “The Dark Knight Returns,” Frank Miller’s 1986 series of comics. As exciting as they were, Miller’s books enshrined a claustrophobic, dystopian approach that has smothered many subsequent screen treatments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Mohamed al-Fayed ‘Was a Monster Enabled by a System,’ Lawyers Say
description: Attorneys for 37 women said they would sue Harrods, the luxury department store, over the rape and sexual assault they say its former owner committed.
content: Lawyers representing dozens of women who have detailed harrowing allegations of sexual assault by Mohamed al-Fayed, the former owner of Harrods, said on Friday that they would launch a civil case against the luxury British department store for allegedly enabling his abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: With World’s Attention Shifting, Some in Gaza Fear They Will Be Forgotten
description: Even as Israel signals that it is moving its focus to its northern border with Lebanon, there has been no pause to its bombardment in Gaza, where residents are facing another winter with little access to food or shelter.
content: After nearly a year of war, fear marks everyday life for Palestinians in Gaza. There is fear of the Israeli warplanes that tear through the skies and carry out deadly airstrikes. There is fear of famine with only a trickle of aid coming in. There is fear of being displaced, yet again, by Israeli evacuation orders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Getty Apologizes for Fireworks Display Gone Awry
description: A planned “explosion event” in Los Angeles by the artist Cai Guo-Qiang left several injured and others shaken.
content: The Getty museum this week found itself having to apologize for the “explosion event” by the artist Cai Guo-Qiang at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum after it left several people injured by falling debris and many others shaken by the sound and smoke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhoda Feng
title: Courting Dark Emotions, and Toying With Audience Expectations
description: Revivals of Michael John LaChiusa’s “See What I Wanna See” and an early work by the “Past Lives” filmmaker look to the spirit world to reflect on our own.
content: The title of Michael John LaChiusa’s “See What I Wanna See” suggests a single perspective, but the show actually offers a kaleidoscopic approach to the truth. It ravels out one story about a murder and a rape only to follow it up, in Rashomon-like fashion, with variations on the same tale that features a businessman, his wife and a sociopath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Don’t Fall Into the ‘Cynicism Trap’
description: Expecting the worst from others is actually bad for our health, experts say.
content: There are days when the world brings out our sardonic side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Sussman Fischler
title: $2.4 Million Homes in Queensland, Australia
description: The eastern Australian state with more than 4,000 miles of coastland offers renovated waterfront apartments, federation-style houses and rural multi-acre estates.
content: This sprawling five-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath house sits on six acres in Eumundi, a rural town of 2,500 in the Noosa Hinterland of Queensland’s Suncoast Region. Historically an agricultural area, Eumundi still has original buildings from the 1800s. These days, it’s known for the artisanal Eumundi market — the largest in Australia, with more than 600 kiosks selling handmade, hand-sewn, home-baked and homegrown products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Sophie Died in 2021. The Album She Left Behind Is Now Complete.
description: “Sophie,” a new LP by the visionary hyperpop producer, traces an arc from introspection to pop pleasures to thoughts of eternity. It will be her final release.
content: In the early hours of Jan. 30, 2021, the visionary hyperpop producer Sophie was living in an apartment in Athens. To get a better view of the full moon, she climbed up a balcony, but slipped and fell. She was 34, and her death brought an outpouring of appreciation for the ways her sonic vocabulary — pointed, wriggly, blippy synthesizer tones and ultra-succinct hooks — had moved so quickly from pop’s experimental fringe to the mainstream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Trump Guide to Civil Discourse
description: “Their rhetoric is causing me to be shot at.”
content: The classic example of chutzpah is that of the child who murders his parents and then pleads for mercy as an orphan. With the 2024 presidential election, we have a new way to illustrate the point: the candidate who condones violence, dehumanizes his opponents and whips his supporters into a frenzy, then turns around to condemn the harsh rhetoric of his opponents and call for peaceful discourse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,190
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 21, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Former N.Y.C. Covid Czar Partied While Preaching Social Distancing
description: In a hidden-camera video posted by a conservative podcaster, Dr. Jay K. Varma boasts about flouting the public health guidelines he insisted others follow.
content: The official in charge of New York City’s pandemic response participated in sex parties and attended a dance party underneath a Wall Street bank during the height of the pandemic, even as he was instructing New Yorkers to stay home and away from others to stop the spread of Covid-19. He acknowledged his transgressions on Thursday after being caught on hidden camera boasting about his exploits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Olivia Nuzzi, New York Magazine Writer, Put on Leave Over R.F.K. Jr. Relationship
description: Ms. Nuzzi told her editors about the relationship that had turned personal, the outlet said. A representative for Mr. Kennedy said the pair had met only once.
content: A star New York Magazine political reporter has been placed on leave after disclosing a personal relationship with the former presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: San Francisco Symphony Chorus Goes on Strike
description: The work stoppage has forced a cancellation of the Verdi Requiem performances.
content: Amid the San Francisco Symphony’s financial troubles, the orchestra’s chorus members on Thursday went on strike, forcing a cancellation of the upcoming performances of Verdi’s Requiem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What an ‘X’ Might Mark
description: Jackson Matz opens our solving weekend.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Is It Better to Buy or Lease a Car? It Depends.
description: The lowest overall cost is to buy a car and keep it for a long time. But leasing usually has lower monthly costs. And leasing an E.V. may come with a tax break.
content: Most people have two options when they want a new car: buy it with a traditional loan or lease it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: How Much Color Can You Fit Into 430 Square Feet?
description: A tiny apartment in London shows that you don’t have to paint everything white to make a space feel larger than life.
content: When Fearghas MacGregor was picking his way through the few, dismal apartments in central London that he could afford to rent in 2011, he looked so miserable that the real estate agent showed him a flat that hadn’t yet come on the market. It was in the King’s Cross neighborhood, an easy commute to his job as a general insurance actuary and within walking distance of the School of Oriental and African Studies, where his American-born wife, Regan Leahy, was studying for her master’s degree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellina Moore
title: When the Horror Is Coming From Under Your Own Skin
description: As “The Substance” hits theaters, here’s a look at eight other films in the goopy subgenre of body horror.
content: In some scary movies, the sources of horror are closer than in your town or even in your house — they’re in your very own skin.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s Victories at the Supreme Court
description: Readers discuss a story about the chief justice’s role. Also: Loving children who are not your own; college football madness.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Trump and Harris Are Courting Pop Stars (Very Differently)
description: A discussion about the ways in which musicians and social media stars, both mainstream and more obscure, have figured into the current presidential campaign.
content: On this week’s episode of Popcast, the pop music critic Jon Caramanica and the pop music reporter Joe Coscarelli discuss how musicians, both mainstream and more obscure, have figured into the current presidential campaign, including:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anita Raghavan
title: Why Nike Just Did It
description: Investors are hoping that replacing John Donahoe as chief executive will lift its stock price and restore the brand’s cool factor.
content: Investors, and apparently some employees, breathed a sigh of relief after Nike said John Donahoe would step down next month as C.E.O. It ends a rocky four-year tenure during which the company lost market share, strained relations with key retail partners and — perhaps most worrisome — lost its cool factor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Britain’s Hard-Right Firebrand Has Big Plans for His Anti-Immigration Party
description: Nigel Farage, a Trump ally and Brexit champion, thinks Reform U.K. can become a major political force. At a conference on Friday, he sought to explain how.
content: A week ago, he was the keynote speaker at a glitzy Chicago dinner for the Heartland Institute, a conservative think tank with a history of denying climate science, where the top tables went for $50,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 11 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
content: Edward (Sebastian Stan), a man with a condition that warps his facial features, discovers his problems are internal after he gets cosmetic surgery and meets another man, Oswald (Adam Pearson), who has the same condition in this dark comedy written and directed by Aaron Schimberg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Bad Bunny Commemorates a Hurricane, and 11 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Jane’s Addiction, Bon Iver, Yola and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes), and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Nasal Flu Vaccine Is Approved for At-Home Use
description: The F.D.A. authorized AstraZeneca’s treatment to be given outside a health care setting, although it will still need a prescription.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday authorized at-home use of FluMist, opening the door for needle-shy people to have easy access to a nasal spray vaccine that is potentially lifesaving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Johnny Kauffman
title: Georgia Election Board Orders Hand-Counting of Ballots
description: Critics say the move could significantly delay the reporting of results in the battleground state and inject chaos into the post-election period.
content: The Georgia State Election Board voted on Friday to force counties to hand-count all ballots cast on Election Day, a move critics say could significantly delay the reporting of results in the battleground state and inject chaos into the post-election period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Friday Briefing: Israel Bombarded Hezbollah
description: Plus, a bright new kid-lit author
content: Hours after Hezbollah’s leader vowed that “retribution will come” to Israel in retaliation for audacious attacks using Hezbollah’s pagers and walkie-talkies, Israel carried out dozens of airstrikes in one of the most intense waves of bombardment this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Don Clark
title: Qualcomm Asked Chip Rival Intel if It Would Consider a Sale
description: While Intel has struggled in recent years, other chipmakers are thriving because of a boom in demand.
content: The chipmaker Qualcomm has approached its rival Intel in recent days about the possibility of acquiring the slumping Silicon Valley giant, two people familiar with the matter said Friday, requesting anonymity because the talks were confidential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Jenny Gross
title: Europe’s New Defense Chief: ‘A King Without a Kingdom’?
description: The European Union has vowed to enhance its military capability. But money is scarce, responsibilities overlap and the new job is less about soldiers than arms manufacturers.
content: Facing an aggressive Russia, a long war in Ukraine and an uncertain American commitment to Europe, Ursula von der Leyen, as president of the European Commission, has created a new post of defense commissioner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: The Conversation That Changed Their Relationship Forever
description: When Samantha Rosensweig, who is well versed at lip reading, picked up on a chat John-Jay Pontrelli had with his cousin, she used the opening.
content: Samantha Lee Rosensweig’s job as a senior marketing manager at Bumble feeds her passion for relationship building. “I love people connecting with people on any sort of level,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump’s Impulse After Robinson Bombshell Report: Ignore, and Power Through
description: CNN’s article scrambled G.O.P. plans for winning North Carolina. People close to Donald Trump are holding out hope Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson will decide to quit the governor’s race.
content: Donald J. Trump’s advisers knew they had a problem in North Carolina. What they were frantically trying to learn was how big it would be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King and Katie Glueck
title: Harris Slams G.O.P. Abortion Bans as a Painful ‘Health Care Crisis’
description: “Donald Trump is the architect of this crisis,” Kamala Harris said in Georgia, where reporting this week found that the deaths of two women were a result of delayed treatment for medication abortions.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris delivered an impassioned speech about abortion rights on Friday in Georgia, accusing Republicans who support abortion bans of causing unnecessary suffering as she described the far-reaching, painful and even deadly consequences of such policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Trump’s Suggestion That Jews Could Cost Him Race Creates Fear of Antisemitic Reprisal
description: Twice on Thursday, the former president said he believed “the Jewish people would have a lot to do with” a loss if Kamala Harris defeated him.
content: Donald Trump’s repeated assertion on Thursday that “the Jewish people would have a lot to do with” his loss if Kamala Harris prevailed on Election Day set off a mix of outrage and concern among Jewish leaders on Friday, raising fears that ardent supporters of the former president could be incited against Jews in an era of rising political violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Whitney Jones, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Daniel Ramirez, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
title: OpenAI’s Reasoning Machine, Instagram Teen Changes and Amazon R.T.O. Drama
description: “They should have just called it Strawberry. At least that’s delicious.”
content: Last week, OpenAI released a preview of its hotly anticipated new model, o1. We discuss what it has excelled at and how it could accelerate the timeline for building superintelligence. Then, we explain why Meta is making teenagers’ Instagram accounts private by default. And, finally, we chat with the New York Times reporter Karen Weise about why Amazon is forcing its corporate employees to go back to working in the office five days a week and whether other companies will follow suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: How Optimus Prime and Megatron Learned to Transform in ‘Transformers One’
description: The director Josh Cooley narrates an action scene from the film.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Ferreira
title: Earth Might Have Had a Ring 466 Million Years Ago
description: Impact craters found around the Earth that were made around the same time could be linked to debris falling from a ring, a new study suggests.
content: If you were to look up from Earth some 466 million years ago, you might have seen a gleaming ring stretching across the sky, some scientists say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Cheng
title: Move Over, Matcha. Strawberry Milk Is Here.
description: Long beloved in Japan, the drink is becoming a fixture on cafe menus in Hawaii and now the mainland, too.
content: As a child growing up on the Hawaiian island of Oahu, Jaron Hanus, 36, a co-owner of the Japanese-inspired cafe Neko Koneko in Honolulu, drank milk with every meal at the insistence of his grandmother. To make it more enticing, she would buy the strawberry-flavored kind from a local Japanese grocery store or make her own by simmering fresh strawberries in milk and honey. Hanus’s wife and business partner, Erin Yonamine, 45, also grew up on Oahu and remembers her grandmother plying her with ichigo (the Japanese word for strawberry) milk and ichigo milk candies from Shirokiya, an erstwhile Japanese department store in Honolulu. When the couple opened Neko Koneko in 2021, they created their own version of their childhood drink — updated with oat milk but just as vibrantly pink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik and OK McCausland
title: Natasha Lyonne Is a Boss (a Boss Trying to Stop Time)
description: Amid Oscar talk for her quiet turn in “His Three Daughters” on Netflix, the spitfire star has become a force as a producer driven by a sense of mortality.
content: Natasha Lyonne has her funeral all planned out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francis Collins
title: Take It From a Scientist. Facts Matter, and They Don’t Care How You Feel.
description: I am deeply troubled by the growing distrust of science in our society, just at the time when its insights are most needed.
content: I am a physician and a scientist. Over 12 years, I had the privilege of serving Presidents Barack Obama, Donald Trump and Joe Biden as the director of the National Institutes of Health. Before that, I led the U.S. component of the Human Genome Project.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hwaida Saad and Ben Hubbard
title: At Funerals and in Hospitals, Talk of Revenge for Pager Attacks
description: After two days of exploding pagers and walkie-talkies, Beirut was a city on edge, with people worried there were bombs in their bags or pockets. Victims’ relatives vowed retribution.
content: In the waiting rooms of a Beirut hospital, exhausted families slumped on couches, waited anxiously for doctors’ updates and wept. Nearby rooms held their loved ones, injured when pagers and walkie-talkies used by Hezbollah suddenly exploded across Lebanon this week, blinding and maiming many of their owners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: GE Vernova May Cut 900 Offshore Wind Jobs as It Scales Back
description: The company, a spinoff from General Electric, has been plagued by financial losses in its wind unit and, more recently, accidents involving the failure of turbine blades.
content: The energy company GE Vernova said on Friday that it would pare back its troubled offshore wind business, which has been hit with financial losses and accidents. The changes, which are aimed at coping with a difficult environment for the wind industry, could result in around 900 job losses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Dangerous Odometer Photography
description: How good does the number have to be to justify taking your phone out to get a picture?
content: Daniel writes: My father has this habit of taking photos of the odometer in his car when it hits certain numbers he finds interesting — while driving. We’ve told him it’s dangerous. His “solution” is to ask his passenger to do it for him. The numbers aren’t even good. (For example: 121213.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Quittner
title: Who Is the ‘Skinny Influencer’ Who Was Barred From TikTok?
description: Liv Schmidt has inspired debates with videos that some believe encourage disordered eating. One social media site tried to remove her.
content: “It’s not a sin to want to be thin,” read a recent social media bio for Liv Schmidt, a polarizing content creator who amassed more than 670,000 followers on TikTok before the company disabled her account last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Fortney
title: Can Young Chefs Save the New York Diner?
description: Across New York City, younger chefs are tweaking the menus, prices and interiors of diners on the brink, but not too much else.
content: Last year, Jackie Carnesi received an unusual proposal. Would she be willing to leave her job as the executive chef of a popular Brooklyn restaurant to work in a nearly century-old New York City diner?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: An Art Installation She Called Home on the Upper East Side
description: The artist Apryl Miller is selling her colorful, full-floor apartment at 188 East 76th Street for $8.75 million. Psychedelic chairs and couches sold separately.
content: The kaleidoscope of colors enveloping the walls, floors and ceilings of Apryl Miller’s home may not be to everyone’s liking. But they served a clear purpose for Ms. Miller, an artist who raised her two daughters in the sprawling Upper East Side apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker Apologizes After Bullying Accusations
description: Dancers said De Keersmaeker, a “godmother of contemporary dance,” ran her company in a tyrannical style that endangered staff members’ health.
content: New projects from the star choreographer Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker are always highly anticipated. But with her dance company touring Europe, a cloud has hung over her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zengerle
title: The Strange Afterlife of Tucker Carlson
description: A year after leaving Fox News, Carlson has figured out how to exercise power and influence in less public ways.
content: On Saturday night in Hershey, Pa., JD Vance will participate in one of the more unusual political events of this presidential campaign. Several thousand people — almost all of whom have paid for the privilege, some as much as $1,600 — will pack into a hockey arena to watch the former Fox News host Tucker Carlson interview Mr. Vance, the Republican Party’s vice-presidential nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Three Mile Island Plans to Reopen as Demand for Nuclear Power Grows
description: The infamous plant, closed since 2019, is getting a new lease on life after Microsoft agreed to buy its electricity to supply a growing fleet of data centers.
content: In a striking sign of renewed interest in nuclear power, Constellation Energy said on Friday that it plans to reopen the shuttered Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania, the site of the worst reactor accident in United States history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson and Rebecca Robbins
title: F.T.C. Accuses Drug Middlemen of Inflating Insulin Prices
description: The case takes aim at the major pharmacy benefit managers, agency officials said, claiming that they favored more expensive insulin products and forced patients to pay more.
content: The Federal Trade Commission said on Friday that it had taken legal action against the three largest pharmacy benefit managers, accusing the drug middlemen of inflating insulin prices and steering patients toward higher-cost insulin products to increase their profits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Ginny Whitehouse
title: Kentucky Town Is Shaken After Local Sheriff Is Charged With Killing Judge
description: The two men were seen getting ready to go to lunch on the day of the shooting. Hours later, Judge Kevin Mullins was dead from multiple gunshot wounds.
content: When Judge Kevin Mullins and Sheriff Shawn Stines, two longtime officials in a rural eastern Kentucky county, were seen getting ready to go to lunch on Thursday, there was no obvious indication of ill will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner and Orlando Mayorquín
title: Kentucky Sheriff Arrested in Shooting Death of Judge
description: The police say a sheriff shot District Judge Kevin Mullins inside the courthouse on Thursday afternoon before turning himself in.
content: The sheriff of a rural eastern Kentucky county walked into a courthouse on Thursday afternoon and shot and killed a district judge in his chambers after an argument, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Harris Praises Taylor Swift’s ‘Courage’ After Endorsement
description: Kamala Harris noted, however, that she still won’t be rooting for the Kansas City Chiefs: “I am a 49ers fan, but who’s mad at anyone for being loyal to their team, right?”
content: Vice President Kamala Harris has received countless endorsements from fellow Democrats and liberal celebrities, but she has made clear that the nod from Taylor Swift just hits different.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Seeking Relief at Recess as Temperatures Soar
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 20, 2024
content: “You plant more trees, you need more gardeners. You put in more irrigation, you need more plumbers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: What Trump Did to the G.O.P., Musk Did to Twitter
description: It’s more toxic but less relevant than ever.
content: There are many damning anecdotes in Kate Conger and Ryan Mac’s new book, “Character Limit: How Elon Musk Destroyed Twitter,” but one from February of last year perfectly captures the astonishing pettiness of the world’s richest man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: Jury Awards $116 Million to Family of Man Who Died in Helicopter Crash
description: When an open-door tourist helicopter crashed into the East River, Trevor Cadigan, 26, and four other passengers were unable to escape from cumbersome safety harnesses.
content: The helicopter flight began with celebration. “All right — let’s do it!” the pilot shouted just before liftoff from the heliport in New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Bergin
title: In Australia, an Old-Fashioned Art Is Having a Revival
description: Young practitioners are helping make stained glass, which fell out of fashion over two decades ago, a vibrant art form in Australia once again.
content: Jonathan Rowatt, a Melbourne hospitality director, said he was tired of cafes featuring “clean lines,” bars fitted out in “varying shades of white” and restaurants with a “beige aesthetic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Thinks It’s Unlikely That Neighbors Ate Your Cat
description: Before starting rumors about Haitians, please make sure your cat is actually missing, Ronnie Chieng implored on “The Daily Show.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan and Kate Kelly
title: Communication Failures Plagued Deadly Trump Rally, Secret Service Finds
description: The agency found that it did not adequately prepare its local partners for the Butler, Pa., event, and its leader also cited lapses including complacency by some agents and technological breakdowns.
content: The Secret Service failed to give clear and crucial directions to its local law enforcement partners at a July campaign rally in Butler, Pa., allowing a would-be assassin to climb onto a warehouse and shoot at former President Donald J. Trump, an agency internal investigation has found.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 20, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 20, 2024.
content: An article on Wednesday about an extremist group affiliated with Al Qaeda claiming responsibility for a deadly assault on two military sites in Mali’s capital, Bamako, misstated the date and circumstances of the last attack by extremist insurgents in Bamako. The attack was in 2016, on a hotel used by military instructors from the European Union, not in 2015 on the Radisson Blu hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward and Adam Rasgon
title: What Is the Radwan Force, the Elite Hezbollah Unit Linked to Ibrahim Aqeel?
description: The Israeli military considers the force a major threat to its northern border and has portrayed Aqeel, whom it claimed to have killed on Friday, as its de facto commander.
content: Israel has long seen Hezbollah, with thousands of trained fighters and a deep arsenal of rockets and other weapons, as the most formidable foe on its borders. And Israeli officials say Hezbollah’s elite Radwan force, in particular, poses a major threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Israel Killed a Top Hezbollah Commander in Lebanon
description: Plus, a baseball game for the ages
content: The Israeli military said today that it had bombed an apartment building in Beirut’s southern suburbs and killed a major figure in Hezbollah’s military command. The strike stoked fears that Israel is driving toward a full-blown war against Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Forbidden Broadway’ Review: Let Them Somewhat Entertain You
description: From its perch way Off Broadway, the long-running satire slings its affectionate arrows at Patti, Audra and the rest.
content: At its best, topical satire, which is what the “Forbidden Broadway” franchise has been slinging for 42 years, is both timely and well targeted. The timeliness means that audience members know the material being ribbed; the targeting makes sure they know why.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass and Diego Mayon
title: On an Italian Island, a Home That Celebrates Color and Craft
description: Atop the volcanic cliffs on the tranquil Salina, one woman has created a respite where art and nature reside in perfect harmony.
content: ON SALINA, THE second largest and most verdant of the seven Aeolian islands, change comes slowly, if at all. The volcanic archipelago off the northern coast of Sicily is a UNESCO World Heritage site but, even without that designation, which places a ban on things like new construction and painting houses a color other than white, Salina might idle forever, quietly serene and proudly inaccessible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Won’t Restore Jill Stein to the Nevada Ballot
description: Democrats had argued that Ms. Stein, the Green Party’s presidential candidate, was ineligible because the party had failed to submit a required statement.
content: The Supreme Court said on Friday that it would not restore the Green Party’s presidential candidate, Jill Stein, to the Nevada ballot in the coming election. Democrats had challenged her eligibility, saying her party had submitted flawed paperwork.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: What the U.S. Has Argued in the Google Ad Tech Antitrust Trial
description: As the government wraps up its case, it has built a picture of how Google has become dominant among companies that buy and sell ads online.
content: Over the past two weeks, lawyers for the Department of Justice have questioned more than a dozen witnesses as they try to prove that Google has broken antitrust laws, part of a second major federal antitrust trial against the tech giant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gilbert Cruz
title: When the Only Screens Were Big
description: A massive, two-volume coffee table book revisits the heyday of classic Hollywood glamour as seen in Life magazine.
content: Some of the most famous images of midcentury American history — Robert Capa’s dispatches from D-Day, a sailor and a nurse entangled in a V-J Day kiss, Robert F. Kennedy lying mortally wounded on the floor of a California hotel kitchen — first appeared in Life magazine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The ‘Crank Realignment’ and the Paranoid Center
description: A few weeks ago, just after Robert Kennedy Jr.’s endorsement of Donald Trump, Matt Yglesias wrote an essay on what he called “the crank realignment” — the recent migration of a lot of conspiratorial, tinfoil-hatted and outsider-knowledge-oriented elements in American politics toward the populist right, and the consolidation of most educated professionals and academics within the Democratic coalition.
content: A few weeks ago, just after Robert Kennedy Jr.’s endorsement of Donald Trump, Matt Yglesias wrote an essay on what he called “the crank realignment” — the recent migration of a lot of conspiratorial, tinfoil-hatted and outsider-knowledge-oriented elements in American politics toward the populist right, and the consolidation of most educated professionals and academics within the Democratic coalition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Amber Bracken
title: What Lies Beneath Canada’s Former Indigenous School Sites Fuels a Debate
description: Despite possible evidence of hundreds of graves at former schools for Indigenous children, challenges in making a clear conclusion have given rise to skeptics.
content: The revelation convulsed all of Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 468
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Sept. 21, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: A North Korean Trash Balloon Hits a Seoul Government Compound, Again
description: Debris was found more than a day after the North’s latest balloon launch. South Korea says it’s essentially impossible to track every balloon.
content: Trash from a balloon sent by North Korea was found in a government complex in Seoul on Friday morning, more than a day after one of the North’s balloon launches was last detected, adding to concerns about South Korea’s potential vulnerability to the provocative new tactic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Harris, With an Online Avalanche, Outspends Trump by Tens of Millions
description: The week of their debate, Kamala Harris outspent Donald Trump by 20 to 1 on Facebook and Instagram. It was just one sign of how uneven their online advertising battle has become.
content: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg, Jess Bidgood, Ben Hubbard, Robert Jimison, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and Tracy Mumford
title: Harris Outspends Trump in Ad Battle, and Israel Bombards Hezbollah
description: Plus, an iconic kitchen brand files for bankruptcy.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: For Economists, Defending Big Business Can Be Big Business
description: The Justice Department’s antitrust chief thinks conflicts of interest are degrading scholarship.
content: Are the world’s most powerful corporations buying the brains of economists and legal scholars? It certainly sounds that way if you listen to the chief antitrust enforcer at the Department of Justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: A Hollywood Actress Finds a Farm, and Her Leading Man, in the Midwest
description: Torrey DeVitto, whose father was Billy Joel’s drummer and mother is Stevie Nicks’s best friend, is a famous actress in her own right. She found love with Jared LaPine in Kalamazoo, Mich.
content: The day after Jared Taylor LaPine graduated from Western Michigan University in 2012, he loaded his car and drove to Los Angeles, his sights set on a career in show business. Eight years later, he was back in his native Kalamazoo, Mich., the glamour of Hollywood thoroughly out of his system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Agee
title: Remember ‘Frindle’? Andrew Clements Had a Sequel Up His Sleeve.
description: More than 25 years later, the pen of another name meets a new generation of wordsmiths.
content: There’s a moment in early childhood when pure, wide-eyed wonder turns into a new kind of curiosity. One day a 3-year-old is perfectly content knowing that the sky is blue, and then all of a sudden they desperately need to know why.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Aric Toler
title: Israeli Soldiers Throw Three Seemingly Lifeless Palestinians Off a Roof
description: Several videos have emerged of the gruesome scene, but it remains unclear if the three were alive or dead at the time.
content: Israeli soldiers threw, pushed and kicked three Palestinians off the roof of a building on Thursday during a military raid in the occupied West Bank town of Qabatiya, according to multiple verified videos of the gruesome incident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: A Concert Celebrates Jimmy Carter’s 100th Birthday, With Music and Thanks
description: The B-52’s, BeBe Winans, Angélique Kidjo, Chuck Leavell and many others performed in Atlanta at a concert honoring the former president, who has been in hospice care.
content: The night included gospel hymns and “America the Beautiful” and the B-52’s lighting up the Fox Theater, one of the oldest auditoriums in Atlanta, with a performance of “Love Shack.” In one moment, the crowd was on its feet as Angélique Kidjo, the acclaimed Beninese musician, sang and danced. In another, they shimmied and sang along to a cover of “Ramblin’ Man.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lei Wang
title: I Wanted to Crave Him, Not Have Him
description: Our intense connection fit no category. Would we be allowed to keep it?
content: One of the most intimate relations in Chinese culture is known as the “zhiji” — the “know-self,” one who knows you like you know yourself. This is a connection outside of any social role, something beyond even best-friendship, like a platonic soul mate. The Chinese describe the feeling a know-self inspires as different from friendly, romantic or familial feelings: It is considered a fourth kind of feeling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: Early Voting Begins in Minnesota, South Dakota and Virginia
description: All three states began sending out mail ballots on Friday and now give people the option of voting in person.
content: Early voting began in Minnesota, South Dakota and Virginia on Friday, letting voters in those states cast ballots while Election Day remains a month and a half away, on Nov. 5.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Eduardo Medina and Michael Wines
title: With Robinson Candidacy, North Carolina Republicans Fear Damage to Years of Gains
description: Explosive posts by the Republican candidate for governor, Mark Robinson, are sending waves of anxiety through a state party that has long been tactical and disciplined.
content: The great Republican wave that swept the South starting in the late 20th Century — the very wave that Lyndon Johnson predicted after signing the Civil Rights Act in 1964 — came relatively late to North Carolina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Marx
title: When a Morning Person and a Night Person Fall in Love
description: Despite differing schedules, Kelly Downey and Gregory Harrington, a celebrated violinist, found a way to make things work.
content: Gregory Anthony Harrington, a celebrated solo violinist, had experienced years of unfulfilling relationships with women he said couldn’t understand his commitment to music. Kelly Cathleen Downey was also fed up with attempts at relationships: Dates, often two to three times a week, typically went nowhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: watershed
description: This word has appeared in 168 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word watershed has appeared in 168 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 10 in “Defeated by A.I., a Legend in the Board Game Go Warns: Get Ready for What’s Next” by Daisuke Wakabayashi and Jin Yu Young:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: ‘La Maison’: Like ‘Succession,’ but Better Dressed (and French)
description: The new Apple TV+’s new series takes the viewer inside two rival Paris fashion houses, with gorgeous people in gorgeous clothes who will do anything for power.
content: “Does she know our favorite dish is eating each other alive?”
source.name: The New York Times

description: Can you sort 8 historical events?

description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

author: By Sarah A. Topol
title: The Deserter
description: He didn’t want to fight in Putin’s war — he just wanted to survive. But to make it back to his family and live in peace, he would have to run.
content: He didn’t want to fight in Putin’s war — he just wanted to survive. But to make it back to his family and live in peace, he would have to run.

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including “The Substance,” a Hollywood satire starring Demi Moore and Margaret Qualley.
content: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including “The Substance,” a Hollywood satire starring Demi Moore and Margaret Qualley.

author: By Trish Bendix
title: The Best of Late Night This Week
description: This week, the hosts focused mostly on news surrounding former President Donald Trump, including the second apparent assassination attempt against him, this time while he was golfing at a Florida club of his, as well as Trump lashing out online about Taylor Swift.
content: This week, the hosts focused mostly on news surrounding former President Donald Trump, including the second apparent assassination attempt against him, this time while he was golfing at a Florida club of his, as well as Trump lashing out online about Taylor Swift.

title: Read the Summary of the Secret Service’s Internal Review
description: The agency released a brief summary of its monthslong inquiry into the failures leading to the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump in July. The complete report is not yet finished.
content: The agency released a brief summary of its monthslong inquiry into the failures leading to the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump in July. The complete report is not yet finished.

author: By Maggie Haberman, Rebecca Suner, John Pappas and James Surdam
title: Trump and Harris Enter the Final Sprint
description: With Election Day just six weeks away, Maggie Haberman, a senior political correspondent for The New York Times, surveys the state of the presidential campaign.
content: With Election Day just six weeks away, Maggie Haberman, a senior political correspondent for The New York Times, surveys the state of the presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Israel vs. Hamas, Hezbollah, Iran — and Itself
description: David Remnick discusses Israel’s overlapping conflicts after nearly a year of war.
content: David Remnick discusses Israel’s overlapping conflicts after nearly a year of war.

author: By Nailah Morgan, Riley Mellen and Haley Willis
title: Airstrike in Lebanon Kills Hezbollah Commander, Israel Says
description: The Israeli military carried out an airstrike in Beirut that it said killed several senior Hezbollah officials, including Ibrahim Aqeel, a commander wanted by the United States for his role in bombings in the 1980s that killed hundreds. The Times verified aftermath footage from the strike that shows a completely flattened high-rise building.
content: The Israeli military carried out an airstrike in Beirut that it said killed several senior Hezbollah officials, including Ibrahim Aqeel, a commander wanted by the United States for his role in bombings in the 1980s that killed hundreds. The Times verified aftermath footage from the strike that shows a completely flattened high-rise building.

title: ‘Transformers One’ | Anatomy of a Scene
description: The director Josh Cooley narrates a sequence from his film.

author: By Sheera Frenkel, Karen Hanley, Nikolay Nikolov and Laura Salaberry
title: How Israel’s Technological Trojan Horse Destabilized Hezbollah
description: The explosion of devices carried by thousands of Hezbollah operatives sowed panic sowed panic and overwhelmed hospitals across Lebanon. Sheera Frenkel, a New York Times technology reporter who has covered cyberwarfare in the Middle East, explains how Israel planned the attacks, according to interviews with 12 officials.
content: The explosion of devices carried by thousands of Hezbollah operatives sowed panic sowed panic and overwhelmed hospitals across Lebanon.
